inscription:
(Leisurely, How?)
(Changing houses, changing houses, how many times have I been changing houses? But is that what my true dwelling is? I envy the gratitude of old age. Into the eastern hills I go out to amuse myself. /  Painting pictures, painting pictures, how many years have I painted? Just like this wandering in forests and streams. An imitation Wang Wei I go out along the Mo river and endure.)

text: Tomioka Tessai is counted among the last of Japan’s Nanga painters. A student of poetry, Japanese philosophy, Confucianism, and a variety of painting styles in his youth, and briefly a Shinto priest, Tessai spent most of his life in Kyoto, where he was a leading figure in late Nanga circles. With his friends, the prominent Meiji-period Nanga Tanomura Chokunyū (1814–1907) and Taniguchi Aizen (1816–1899), Tessai helped establish the Japan Nanga Society (Nihon Nanga Kyōkai) in 1896. In the final year of his life, he was conferred with the title, “Artisan of the Imperial Household” (Teishitsu gigei’in).
title: Portraits of Ike Taiga and His Calligraphies in Seal and Grass Styles
